original_conversation.content: [relieved] God, we actually did it. The meal plan reform went through, finally. That's not just a statistic, that's... hmm, that's real people who were skipping breakfast, stretching dining dollars until they ran out mid-semester. [anxious] The board fought me so hard on this. "Budget constraints," they kept saying. [frustrated] But I did the math over and over—we could reallocate from that ridiculous new scoreboard fund and nobody would even— [trailing off] well, except maybe the alumni donors... [chuckle] But honestly? When you're in this position, when you have this kind of, um, responsibility, you can't just sit there and watch students choose between textbooks and food. [passionately] That's not what education should be about! [short pause] And the mental health services expansion starts next month. [excited] We're going from two counselors to eight! [very quietly] I remember being a student here, waiting three weeks for an appointment when I was falling apart. [empathetically] Nobody should have to wait that long when they're struggling. [confidently] This is why I ran for this position. Not for the, er, the fancy title or the networking. [sincere] For this. For actually making things better.
